text: our British citizens are being advised
not to travel anywhere in the world for
the next 30 days because of the corona
virus pandemic the foreign secretary
Donna Crabb made the announcement in the
House of Commons
so with immediate effect I've taken the
decision to advise British nationals
against non-essential travel globally
for an initial period of 30 days and of
course subject to ongoing review now Mr
Speaker I should emphasize this decision
has been taken based on the domestic
measures introduced here in the UK
alongside the changes to border and a
range of other restrictions which are
now being taken by countries right
around the world following today's
change in travel advice British
nationals who decide that they still
need to travel abroad should do so fully
aware of the increased risks of doing so
and that obviously includes the risk
that they may not be able to get home if
travel restrictions are subsequently put
in place that they hadn't anticipated so
we urge anyone still considering travel
to be realistic about the level of
disruption they are willing and able to
endure and to make decisions in light of
the unprecedented conditions that we
face
we've been our diplomatic correspondent
James lander watching that and the
question for many is what why now well
you heard the foreign sector they're
talking about there's being
unprecedented circumstances this is an
unprecedented move no British Foreign
Secretary has ever told the British
people don't go abroad unless it's
absolutely essential and it reflects two
things one is the advice given by the
government yesterday namely if you're
telling everybody don't travel unless
it's really essential in the UK you've
got to pretty much copy that for
overseas but secondly and perhaps more
importantly they do not want more and
more Brits to be traveling overseas and
getting into difficulties because
there's it's a pretty chaotic world out
there at the moment countries are
throwing up a lot of border restrictions
travel restrictions willy-nilly a lot of
the time without giving other countries
any kind of notice and there is an
increasing risk in the government's view
that there will be vulnerable Brits
trapped abroad unable to get back and
they don't want to add to that stock
there's already a fair number of them
they don't want that to be increased so
so that's really why they're doing there
I think the there are some exceptions of
course the exceptions are primarily for
freight and for you know business goods
that simply have to come into the into
the country and for the moment to that
advice will last for 30 days but it's
going to be kept under constant review
so it will probably change so
unprecedented announcement is it is it
problematic announcement well it's
difficult because what it doesn't really
solve the British nationals who are
overseas problem when the foreign sector
was giving his statement to Parliament
MP after M people standing up saying
look what about my constituent who is
trapped in country X they there are no
flights home their insurance is about to
run out their hotel is about to kick
them out so they haven't got any money
the insurance companies saying we'll
only pay you when you get back how does
that solve that and frankly all the
foreign secretary really say was look
you know the UK government is not saying
to these people you must return
immediately but they're saying look
there is a window here where some
flights may be available where some
countries may really take some of those
restrictions open and open them up so
that some Brits can get home but the
foreign sector was very clear
repatriation flights are costly they are
complicated and he said they're becoming
harder to achieve so I think they are
hoping for some risk you know if there's
a chance to go they should move now is
there a sense that the government all
government departments are now singing
from the same hymn sheet if you like
yeah yes yes and no I mean government is
government and and think the departments
move in sort of different phases now but
this is you know the Foreign Office
saying look this is our side of this
particular case here and there are going
to be a lot of instances of British
nationals trapped abroad who find
themselves in difficult circumstances
now and there will be a test of the
extent of the remit if you like of the
British government cuz frankly the
British government does not have the
resources to fly everybody home ok James
thank you much james land a lot
